page.title: 17South West Nercwys - History
page.content: The major portion of this area was owned for centuries by the Nercwys Hall and Plas Ucha estates. In the early 20th century both estates sold their properties, now almost all farms and houses are owner-occupied. The common land was used for hare coursing until the enclosure act 1831, when the lower parts of the Common were enclosed with parallel boundaries of stone wall and hedge as seen today. The houses and buildings are welsh stone and slate, some built in the late 17th century. Plas Ucha farmhouse and barn were built in the 17th century. Plas Ucha cottage, stone with thatched roof, has now been extended. Llewelyn farmhouse, with its own private chapel, was built of stone in the 18th century. The Orangery at Nercwys Hall is an 1813 Gothic building.
